data.meta_description: Panama, a vibrant Central American nation celebrated for its iconic canal, lush rainforests, and dynamic urban centers, has established itself as a tourist place
data.text:
Reading Time: 21 minutes

Panama, a vibrant Central American nation celebrated for its iconic canal, lush rainforests, and dynamic urban centers, has established itself as a significant player in the realm of international travel. Panama’s passport grants its holders visa-free or visa-on-arrival access to 149 countries as of August 2024, offering considerable travel freedom. This ranking highlights Panama’s commitment to fostering international relationships and enhancing the mobility of its citizens, making it an appealing choice for those seeking extensive global access.

TTW Editor Mr. Anup Kumar Keshan says: “Panama citizens can enjoy visa-free or visa-on-arrival access to 149 countries as of August 2024, highlighting the nation’s strong global connectivity. Since 2021, Panama has been proudly carbon-negative, with its lush forests capturing more carbon than the country emits. The economy is thriving, driven by dynamic sectors like construction, trade, and tourism. The new administration is focused on implementing strategic reforms to ensure long-term growth and stability, making Panama an even more attractive destination for global travelers and investors.”

Economic Overview and Tourism Trends

In 2021, Panama saw around 360,000 outbound departures, marking a 23.3% drop compared to the previous year. This decline aligns with global travel trends impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic and its subsequent effects.

Carbon-Negative Achievement

Notably, since 2021, Panama has become one of the first carbon-negative countries, with its forests capturing more carbon than the country emits, contributing significantly to combating the climate crisis.

Economic Growth and Sector Performance

In 2023, Panama’s economy grew by an estimated 6.5%, driven by sectors such as construction, trade, and tourism. The country exited the Financial Action Task Force’s list of high-risk non-cooperative countries, which is expected to bring positive economic benefits.

Fiscal Challenges for the New Administration

The new administration, starting July 1st, will need to address structural fiscal challenges, including pension fund reform and climate disruptions, to sustain growth and maintain a robust fiscal outlook.

Major Airports and Airlines of Panama

Major Airports:

Tocumen International Airport (PTY)

Location: Panama City

Description: The largest and busiest airport in Panama, serving as the main international gateway to the country. It is a major hub for connecting flights across the Americas and beyond.

Enrique Malek International Airport (DAV)

Location: David, Chiriquí

Description: Serves the western part of Panama, providing both domestic and international flights. It is crucial for tourism and business in the region.

Scarlett Martínez International Airport (RIH)

Location: Rio Hato

Description: Primarily serves the beach resort areas of Panama’s Pacific coast. It handles seasonal and charter flights aimed at tourists.

Albrook “Marcos A. Gelabert” International Airport (PAC)

Location: Panama City

Description: Mainly serves domestic flights and some regional flights. It is located closer to Panama City’s downtown area compared to Tocumen.

Major Airlines:

Copa Airlines

Description: The flag carrier of Panama, Copa Airlines operates from its main hub at Tocumen International Airport. It offers extensive connectivity throughout the Americas and the Caribbean.

Air Panama

Description: The second largest airline in Panama, Air Panama primarily offers domestic flights and some regional services. It operates out of Albrook “Marcos A. Gelabert” International Airport.

Wingo

Description: A low-cost carrier based in Colombia that operates flights to and from Panama, providing affordable travel options within Latin America.

These airports and airlines are pivotal in connecting Panama domestically and internationally, supporting both tourism and business travel.

Things to do in United Kingdom:

Windsor Castle

Location: Windsor & Eton, England, Europe

Top Choice in Windsor & Eton

Windsor Castle, the world’s largest and oldest continuously occupied fortress, is a majestic vision of battlements and towers. It’s one of the principal residences of the Queen, used for state occasions, with the Royal Standard flying from the Round Tower when she’s home.

Inside Windsor Castle

The castle precincts are divided into the Lower, Middle, and Upper Wards. A visit will take you through lavish State Apartments and beautiful chapels, with certain areas potentially off-limits if in use.

Highlights Include:

Inner Hall: Reopened to the public in 2019, it features intricate Regency ceiling bosses and offers an uninterrupted view of the Long Walk.

Queen Mary’s Dolls’ House: An astonishing creation designed at 1:12 scale, featuring fully functional plumbing, electric lights, tiny Crown Jewels, a silver service, a wine cellar, and even a fleet of six cars.

State Apartments: Around two dozen rooms are open to the public, filled with historical artifacts, opulent furniture, tapestries, and paintings by renowned artists like Hans Holbein and Rembrandt.

St George’s Chapel: Commissioned by Edward IV in 1475, this chapel is a fine example of Perpendicular Gothic architecture and serves as a royal mausoleum.

Changing of the Guard

A fabulous spectacle with tunes from a military band and smartly attired troops, the Changing of the Guard takes place in the Lower Ward or the Quadrangle in the Upper Ward when the Queen is in residence. It usually occurs at 11 am on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays.

Tickets

Entry is timed, and tickets must be booked in advance. The price includes a multimedia guide. Your ticket can be converted to a year-long pass – just ask a member of staff before you leave.

Tower of London

Location: London, England, Europe

Top Choice in London

Why You Should Go

Few places in the UK are as rich in history, legend, and superstition as the Tower of London. This iconic fortress offers a journey through centuries of architectural marvels and historical significance. It houses the world’s largest diamond, the Koh-i-Nûr, and offers free tours from the famed Yeoman Warders, also known as “Beefeaters.” The Tower’s history as a royal residence, treasury, mint, armory, zoo, and infamous prison makes it a captivating destination.

Most visitors flock to the Waterloo Barracks to marvel at the Crown Jewels, including the platinum crown of the late Queen Mother, adorned with the 106-carat Koh-i-Nûr diamond, and the Imperial State Crown. The collection is showcased on slow-moving walkways, allowing visitors to fully appreciate these priceless symbols of the British monarchy.

Why You Should Go

Hyde Park, one of London’s most beloved green spaces, spans 142 hectares of neat gardens, wild expanses of grass, and magnificent trees. This central urban oasis offers a variety of fascinating sights and hosts live concerts and events throughout the year.

The park’s eastern half features expansive lawns perfect for picnics and relaxation on sunny days. In contrast, the western half boasts more untamed areas with trees and wild grass. The Rose Garden offers a splash of color and shade year-round, while the Holocaust Memorial Garden provides a quiet, reflective space. Other highlights include the Serpentine and the Diana, Princess of Wales Memorial Fountain.

From March to October, you can hire a deck chair for a fee, making it easy to find a comfortable spot to enjoy the park’s beauty.

Things to do in Saudi Arabia

Prophet’s Mosque, Saudi Arabia

The Prophet’s Mosque is a must-visit destination for any traveler to Saudi Arabia. As one of the only two mosques in the world that can host a million worshippers, it holds profound significance for Muslims worldwide. Built by the Prophet Muhammad in AD 622, the mosque encompasses his final resting place, along with the first two caliphs, beneath the iconic green dome erected by the Ottomans. This historic site also covers the location of the Prophet’s original house, a simple mud-and-wood structure adjacent to the mosque.

Al Mudaifar Mosque, Saudi Arabia

Nestled amidst a lush forest of palms, Al Mudaifar Mosque offers a charming glimpse into the historic Saudi Arabia of the Najd region. This quaint mud-brick mosque, featuring a tall round minaret and an intricately engraved wooden door, has been carefully restored to maintain its authentic character. Inside, storm lanterns hang from ceilings made of palm trunks, and a red patterned carpet covers the floor. The simple white mihrab (niche indicating the direction of Mecca) is framed by wooden shutters, with neatly arranged green Qurans adding to the serene atmosphere.

Masmak Fortress, Riyadh, Saudi Arabia

Masmak Fortress, a squat fortification surrounded by desert sands, stands as a testament to Saudi Arabia’s rich history. Built around 1865, this impressive fortress looks like a scene straight out of a movie, symbolizing the might of an empire. The fortress is famously known for the daring 1902 raid by Ibn Saud, during which a spear was hurled at the main entrance with such force that its head remains embedded in the door to this day. The exhibits inside feature captivating maps and photographs of Saudi Arabia from 1912 to 1937, displayed in galleries converted from traditional diwans (living rooms).

Things to do in Brazil

The Enchantment of Copacabana Beach

Imagine yourself on the iconic sands of Copacabana Beach, a place where the vibrant energy of Rio de Janeiro meets the tranquil beauty of the Atlantic Ocean. This 4km stretch of scalloped shoreline is a mosaic of culture, sport, and sheer beauty.

The Vibrant Pulse of Copacabana

Activities and Atmosphere: Copacabana is alive with activity. From the rhythmic chants of soccer players to the refreshing taste of caipirinhas from local kiosks, there’s a pulse to this beach that captivates every visitor. Favela kids showcase their soccer prowess while beach vendors call out their goods among the sun-kissed bodies.

Sections of the Beach:

Stock Market (LGBTQ+ section): Between the Copacabana Palace Hotel and Rua Fernando Mendes, you’ll find the gay and cross-dresser section, easily identifiable by the rainbow flag.

Young Athletes: Near Rua Santa Clara, young football and futevôlei players dominate the sands.

Family and Retirees: Postos 5 and 6 offer a mix of favela kids and carioca retirees, creating a vibrant community atmosphere.

Fishermen’s Colony: Next to Forte de Copacabana, this area is where local fishermen gather, giving it a unique, traditional charm.

Leme Beach: As Copacabana curves north, it transitions into the quieter sands of Leme. This area, marked by Av Princesa Isabel, hosts older residents and children from nearby favelas, offering a more laid-back vibe.

Safety and Nightlife

Safety Tips: While the beach is well-lit at night and patrolled by police, it’s best to stay near the lively beach kiosks after dark. Avoid Av NS de Copacabana during weekends when it’s less populated.

Nearby Attractions

Parque Nacional da Tijuca: Just 2 miles away, this tropical jungle preserve offers a glimpse into Rio’s lush Atlantic rainforest.

Sugar Loaf Cable Car (Pão de Açúcar): A 2.25-mile trip to the peak provides stunning views, especially at sunset.

Ipanema Beach: 2.19 miles away, this beach is famous for its diverse subcultures, demarcated by different postos.

Cristo Redentor: Standing atop Corcovado, 2.16 miles away, this iconic statue offers a serene gaze over the city.

Maracanã Football Stadium: At 5.1 miles, this stadium is a must-visit for football enthusiasts.

Jardim Botânico: This 137-hectare garden, 2.59 miles away, is a botanical paradise.

Instituto Moreira Salles: Located 3.53 miles away, this cultural center showcases Brazil’s artistic heritage.

Museu de Arte do Rio: 5.13 miles away, this museum highlights Rio’s artistic revival.

Floresta Nacional do Tapajós

Welcome to Floresta Nacional do Tapajós, where the awe-inspiring primary rainforest of the Amazon awaits. This pristine natural reserve in Pará, Brazil, offers a captivating glimpse into one of the world’s most biodiverse regions.

The Essence of Tapajós

Primary Rainforest: Floresta Nacional do Tapajós is a haven for those seeking an authentic Amazonian experience. The primary rainforest here boasts towering trees and a serene ambiance that transports visitors to a different world. Wildlife sightings are possible, with a chance to encounter various bird species, primates, and occasionally, even a jaguar.

Access Points: You can access this natural wonder from Santarém or Alter do Chão. Both locations serve as gateways to the heart of the rainforest.

Village Trails:

Maguarí: Offers well-maintained trails that showcase the region’s lush flora.

Jamaraquá: A starting point for deeper forest excursions.

São Domingo: Known for its scenic forest paths leading to the primary rainforest.

Nearby Attractions in Pará

Belterra: 12.4 miles away, this town was once home to Henry Ford’s Fordlândia operations in the 1940s. It’s an easy day trip from Santarém, offering a peek into industrial history.

Ilha do Amor: 21.87 miles from Tapajós, this “Island of Love” is especially picturesque during low water months (August to December).

Lago Verde: At 22.04 miles, this expansive lake is perfect for swimming, snorkeling, and wildlife spotting, including a resident family of monkeys.

ZooFIT: Located 29.55 miles away, this rehabilitation center provides educational tours about animal conservation.

Ponta do Cururú: 23.96 miles from the forest, this sandy point is famous for the pink and grey dolphins that gather offshore in the evenings.

Praia do Cajueiro: A pleasant beach 21.82 miles away, wrapping around to the Tapajós River, perfect for a relaxing day out.

The Iconic Edifício Copan

Architectural Significance: Edifício Copan’s distinctive serpentine facade and narrow brises soleil (permanent sunshades) make it one of São Paulo’s most recognizable structures. Niemeyer’s design aimed to integrate different social classes by incorporating both luxurious apartments for the affluent and smaller studios for the working class. This architectural gem is not just a building but a symbol of unity in a class-conscious city.

Visiting Edifício Copan:

Ground-floor Shopping Arcade: Accessible anytime, this snaking, sloping arcade offers a variety of shops and services.

Rooftop Views: Typically open on weekdays at 10:30am and 3:30pm, the rooftop provides spectacular views of São Paulo. Note that visits are temporarily suspended. When available, the 15-minute rooftop visit feels wonderfully unrushed despite minimal railings, enhancing the experience. Be sure to check in at Bloco F at least 30 minutes in advance as space is limited.

Nearby Attractions in São Paulo

Mercado Municipal: 1.04 miles away, this belle epoque market features stained glass and vast domes, offering a delightful urban market experience.

Museu de Arte de São Paulo: Just 1.24 miles from Copan, this museum boasts Latin America’s most comprehensive collection of Western art.

Mosteiro São Bento: Located 0.73 miles away, this historic church dates back to 1598, with a neo-Gothic facade from the early 20th century.

Farol Santander: 0.69 miles from Edifício Copan, this skyscraper offers one of the best panoramas of the city from its 161m-high observation deck.

Pina_Luz: This neoclassical museum, 1.1 miles away, houses an extensive collection of art and was rebranded as ‘Pina_Luz’ in 2017.

Museu Xingu: At 1.66 miles, this lesser-known museum offers a quaint cafe and showcases indigenous handicrafts and cultural artifacts.

Estação da Luz: A stunning late-Victorian train station located 0.99 miles away, it is a must-see for its architectural beauty.

Beco do Batman: 2.74 miles from Copan, this alley is renowned for its vibrant street art and cultural significance.

Things to do in Germany

Aachener Dom: A Historic Marvel in Aachen, Germany

Aachener Dom, a site of immense historical and architectural significance in Aachen, Germany. This magnificent cathedral is not just a symbol of the city’s rich past but also a beacon for pilgrims and history enthusiasts from around the world.

The Majesty of Aachener Dom

Historical Significance: Aachener Dom, also known as Aachen Cathedral, is the final resting place of Charlemagne, the first Holy Roman Emperor. It has been the coronation site for over 30 German kings and a pilgrimage destination since the 12th century.

Visiting Aachener Dom: Before entering the cathedral, stop by Dom Information for tour details and tickets for the cathedral treasury. English tours run daily at 2pm, providing insightful glimpses into the cathedral’s storied past.

Architectural Wonders

Pfalzkapelle: The oldest and most impressive section of the cathedral is Charlemagne’s palace chapel, the Pfalzkapelle. Completed in 800 AD, it stands as an outstanding example of Carolingian architecture. The chapel features an octagonal dome encircled by a 16-sided ambulatory supported by antique Italian pillars. The colossal brass chandelier, a gift from Emperor Friedrich Barbarossa, adds to its grandeur.

Gothic Choir: In 1414, a Gothic choir was added to the chapel to accommodate the influx of pilgrims. It houses treasures such as the Pala d’oro, a gold-plated altar-front depicting Christ’s Passion, and a jewel-encrusted gilded copper pulpit from the 11th century.

Charlemagne’s Throne: Located in the upstairs gallery, Charlemagne’s imperial throne, made of white marble, served as the coronation throne for 30 German kings. Access is restricted to guided tours, ensuring visitors can appreciate its historical significance.

Pilgrimage Relics

Aachener Dom houses some of Christianity’s most revered relics, displayed every seven years (next in 2021), drawing over 100,000 pilgrims. These include:

Christ’s loincloth

Mary’s cloak

The cloth that wrapped John the Baptist’s decapitated head

Swaddling clothes from Jesus’ infancy

Nearby Aachen Attractions

Domschatzkammer: Located 0.06 miles from the cathedral, this treasury is a veritable mother lode of gold, silver, and jewels, including the silver-and-gold bust of Charlemagne.

Puppenbrunnen: A whimsical modern fountain just 0.03 miles away, featuring mechanical art and historical symbols.

Katschhof: This historic square, 0.07 miles from the cathedral, offers a serene spot to contemplate Aachen’s rich history.

Centre Charlemagne: A museum located 0.08 miles away, exploring the life and times of Charlemagne and Aachen’s historical significance.

Couven Museum: At 0.08 miles, this museum showcases the living spaces of 17th- and 18th-century patricians.

Rathaus: Aachen’s splendid Gothic town hall, located 0.1 miles away, features statues of German rulers, including 30 kings crowned in Aachen.

Suermondt Ludwig Museum: A museum 0.51 miles away, known for its medieval sculpture and fine works by artists like Cranach, Dürer, and Macke.

Zugspitze: Germany’s Rooftop

Elevate your travel experiences with a trip to Zugspitze, Germany’s highest peak. Located in Garmisch-Partenkirchen, this majestic mountain offers breathtaking views and an unforgettable adventure.

Journey to the Summit

The Scenic Ascent: Start your journey in Garmisch-Partenkirchen aboard a cogwheel train (Zahnradbahn) that takes you along the mountain base to Eibsee, a picturesque forest lake. From Eibsee, the super-steep Eibsee-Seilbahn cable car lifts you to the summit at 2962 meters.

Admire the Panoramic Views: On clear days, the views from Zugspitze extend into four countries, providing a 360-degree panorama of the Alps. After soaking in the vistas, descend via the Gletscherbahn cable car to the Zugspitze glacier at 2600 meters, and then take the cogwheel train back to Garmisch.

Beat the Crowds: To make the most of your visit, start early in the day and avoid weekends when the site is busiest.

Nearby Garmisch-Partenkirchen Attractions

Schloss Linderhof: 10.21 miles away, this small yet luxurious palace was King Ludwig II’s favorite residence, adorned with opulent treasures.

Schloss Neuschwanstein: Located 14.57 miles from Zugspitze, this fairy-tale castle inspired Disney’s Sleeping Beauty castle and is a must-see for its romantic architecture.

Schloss Hohenschwangau: 14.95 miles away, this sun-yellow castle was King Ludwig II’s childhood home and summer retreat.

Schloss Ambras: At 23.94 miles, this Renaissance castle sits atop a hill surrounded by beautiful gardens, once owned by Archduke Ferdinand II.

Hofburg: 21.87 miles away, this impressive white castle in Innsbruck was originally built in the 15th century and expanded over the years.

Hofkirche: Innsbruck’s Gothic royal court church, located 21.91 miles from Zugspitze, is one of Europe’s finest.

Goldenes Dachl: 21.82 miles away, this golden-roofed building is Innsbruck’s most distinctive landmark, built for Holy Roman Emperor Maximilian I.

Rosengartenschlucht: A family-friendly hike 17.01 miles from Zugspitze, offering a scenic loop through a dramatic gorge with 200-meter-high walls.

Explore the Grandeur of Schloss Charlottenburg in Berlin

Step into the splendor of Berlin’s past with a visit to Schloss Charlottenburg. This magnificent palace, nestled in the City West & Charlottenburg district, is a testament to the opulence and grandeur of the Hohenzollern dynasty, which ruled from 1415 to 1918.

The Majesty of Schloss Charlottenburg

Historical Significance: Originally a petite summer retreat, Schloss Charlottenburg grew into an exquisite baroque palace adorned with opulent private apartments, richly decorated festival halls, and an impressive collection of precious porcelain and paintings by 18th-century French masters.

Visiting Schloss Charlottenburg:

Altes Schloss: The oldest section of the palace is an extravaganza of stucco, brocade, and overall opulence. Highlights include the Oak Gallery, a wood-paneled festival hall adorned with family portraits; the Oval Hall, offering stunning garden views; Friedrich I’s bedchamber with the first-ever bathroom in a baroque palace; and the fabulous Porcelain Chamber, filled with Chinese and Japanese blue ware.

Neuer Flügel: The flamboyant private chambers of Frederick the Great, designed in 1746 by Georg Wenzeslaus von Knobelsdorff, are among the palace’s most beautiful rooms. Notable features include the White Hall banquet room, the mirrored and gilded Golden Gallery, and paintings by Watteau, Pesne, and other 18th-century French masters. The apartments of Queen Luise, wife of King Friedrich Wilhelm III, are also located in this wing, showcasing lavish chandeliers, period furniture, and hand-painted silk wall coverings.

Neuer Pavillon: Designed by Karl Friedrich Schinkel, this adjacent pavilion served as a summer retreat for Friedrich Wilhelm III and now houses paintings from the Romantic and Biedermeier periods.

The Palace Park

Schlossgarten Charlottenburg: The sprawling palace park is a blend of formal French gardens and picturesque English landscapes. Enjoy a leisurely stroll through shady walkways, flower beds, and manicured lawns. Discover the pint-sized palace called Belvedere, now an elegant setting for porcelain masterpieces by the royal manufacturer KPM.

Mausoleum: Across the carp pond lies the 1810 neoclassical Mausoleum, where various royals, including Kaiser Wilhelm I and his wife, are entombed in ornate marble sarcophagi.

Admission Tips

Charlottenburg+ Day Pass: Each building at Schloss Charlottenburg charges separate admission fees. To make the most of your visit, invest in the ‘Charlottenburg+’ day pass for access to everything. The palace gets busy, so arrive early on weekends and during the summer to avoid crowds.
